learning_outcomes.description: understand concepts of elementary number theory
solve problems in number theory using modular arithmetic
understand concepts of abstract algebra, including groups, rings, and fields
understand abstract vector spaces and linear algebra concepts such as eigenvalues, diagonalisability, and Jordan canonical form
apply the mathematical techniques of the course to problems from other disciplines
present clear and concise mathematical arguments

assessments.task_description: Assignment 1 requires you to answer a set of questions and submit your written solutions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignment 1 must be submitted electronically through Blackboard as a single pdf file. Ensure that your name, student number and tutorial group number appear on the first page of your submission. Make sure that your pdf file is legible and that the file size is not excessive. Use the assignment submission link in Blackboard to submit the pdf file.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: Assignment 2 requires you to answer a set of questions and submit your written solutions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignment 2 must be submitted electronically through Blackboard as a single pdf file. Ensure that your name, student number and tutorial group number appear on the first page of your submission. Make sure that your pdf file is legible and that the file size is not excessive. Use the assignment submission link in Blackboard to submit the pdf file.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final examination in this course will be held during the end-of-semester examination period. It will be an invigilated, closed-book, in-person exam held on campus.

Casio FX82 and UQ approved and labelled calculators will be allowed but are not required.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description: You are required to research applications of the theoretical material covered in the course, and submit either a written project or a video on this topic. Further details and assistance will be provided during the semester.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission details will be provided closer to the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures define the course material. They set out the basic theory and demonstrate techniques for problem solving. They cover all the core material required for the course. They are also used to provide administrative information for the course. During the lectures, students are encouraged to answer or ask questions when opportunities arise.

They cover all the core material required for the course. They are also used to provide administrative information for the course. During the lectures, students are encouraged to answer or ask questions when opportunities arise.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Exam week 2(24 Feb - 22 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Independent study

The expected workload for a 2 unit course at UQ is 10 hours per week (on average). In addition to time spent at lectures and tutorials, students are expected to revise the course material, work through problem sets, and complete assignments.
learning_activities.topic_description: Independent study The expected workload for a 2 unit course at UQ is 10 hours per week (on average). In addition to time spent at lectures and tutorials, students are expected to revise the course material, work through problem sets, and complete assignments.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(03 Mar - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Practicals

Tutorials provide students with an opportunity for individual assistance. Students will be given sets of problems to complete during tutorials, giving them the opportunity to practise mathematical techniques with assistance available from a tutor and/or from their peers. The tutorials also provide an opportunity to ask questions about other aspects of the course, including assignments.
